properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong, possibly damaging winds will gust to 90 kilometres per hour beginning overnight tonight through Sunday morning. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-30T02:10:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T10:11:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2124385677.2019
Area: Blanc-Sablon
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A wintery mix of precipitation is expected for southern Manitoba beginning early Friday and lasting into Sunday. A Colorado low will cross the northern plains today and bring periods of snow and freezing drizzle to southern Manitoba. The mix of precipitation will begin in the southwest spreading eastward throughout the morning. There will be the potential for prolonged periods of freezing drizzle leading to icy conditions on sidewalks and roadways, though exact timing and duration remain uncertain at this time. This mix of precipitation will continue through late Saturday in many areas. Conditions will improve Saturday night into Sunday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-30T02:38:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T10:39:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3371335006.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Accumulating snow will continue. Total snowfall: 5 to 10 cm except near 30 cm over higher terrain. Locations: Upper Lake Melville and Eagle River. Time span: continuing until Sunday morning. Remarks: Snow accumulations will vary considerably, with the largest totals occurring over the highest elevations. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate. Motorists should be prepared for winter driving conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-30T06:58:54-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T14:59:54-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4041783319.2019
Area: Upper Lake Melville, Eagle River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Southwesterly winds will reach up to 100 km/h beginning overnight tonight. These winds will diminish Saturday afternoon. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Large waves, pounding surf and elevated water levels are expected. Wave heights: 3 to 7 metres. Locations: North facing shorelines of The Gulf of St. Lawrence and Northumberland Strait. Time span: Today, tonight, Saturday, then subsiding late Sunday. Remarks: The highest waves will be at north facing shorelines of the Magdalen Islands, Prince Edward Island and Cape Breton where waves of 5 to 7 metres and water levels of a metre above tide are expected. Over north facing shorelines of New Brunswick and mainland Nova Scotia, wave heights are expected to be in the 3 to 4 metre range with a storm surge of 50 cm to 1 metre. Shore or beach erosion and damage to coastal infrastructure is possible in vulnerable areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-30T06:37:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T14:38:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1456114258.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A wintry mix of precipitation is expected. Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm over higher elevations. Total rainfall: 10 to 20 mm over lower elevations. Locations: Deer Lake and the Humber Valley area. Time span: continuing until Saturday evening. Remarks: A mixture of snow and rain will today and persist through Saturday. Lower areas in the valley will receive mainly rain with just a couple centimetres of snow. Adjacent higher terrain, however, will receive mainly snow with potential for significant accumulations. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-30T06:43:55-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall, followed by significant rainfall, is expected. Total snowfall: 2 to 5 cm, except 8 to 12 cm inland and over higher terrain. Total rainfall: 30 to 50 mm. Locations: Avalon and Burin Peninsulas. Time: continuing until Saturday evening. Remarks: Wet snow will transition to rain, at times heavy, later this morning. The rain is expected to ease to drizzle or showers this afternoon, but periods of rain will likely redevelop tonight. Wet weather will then continue into Saturday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds gusting near 70 km/h combined with fresh snow could bring blizzard conditions beginning this morning. These conditions are forecast to persist until Friday evening. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-30T03:46:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T11:47:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3257031862.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A wintery mix of precipitation is expected for southeastern Saskatchewan Friday and Saturday. A Colorado low moving through the northern plains of the United States will bring periods of light snow and freezing drizzle to southeastern Saskatchewan. Patchy freezing drizzle has developed overnight and will continue over the next 24 hours. Extended periods of freezing drizzle are possible, but the exact timing and location is uncertain at this time. This mix of precipitation will continue through late Saturday before moving out of the area. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-30T02:36:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T10:37:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1969564285.2019

properties.Title: Update: High Water Advisory Alert Is Being Issued For The Roseau River From Gardenton To Dominion City
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre has issued a High Water Advisory for the Roseau River from Gardenton to Dominion City due to expected high flows. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions by the local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca or stay tuned to local media.
Expires: 2019-11-30T08:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2019-11-29T08:19:48-06:00, D17B89C0-C301-FA2E-E37E-E9973869E538
Area: Roseau River from Gardenton to Dominion City
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Persistent snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Snow squalls with total amounts of 20 to 40 cm is expected. Locations: Northern mainland Nova Scotia, Cape Breton Highlands and eastern Prince Edward Island. Time span: This afternoon to Saturday evening. Remarks: A cold northerly flow and strong winds will lead to the development of snow squalls starting this afternoon. Accumulations will vary with the intensity of the snow squalls with the highest amounts expected over the Cape Breton Highlands. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snow squall warnings are issued when bands of snow form that produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-30T06:36:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T14:37:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3067642819.2019
Area: Pictou County, Antigonish County, Inverness County - south of Mabou, Inverness County - Mabou and north, Victoria County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

Accumulations will be variable, with the highest amounts occurring inland and over elevated terrain. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Conditions are favourable for the development of snow squalls between this afternoon and Saturday evening. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-30T01:48:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T09:49:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2505462297.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected, with accumulating snowfall. Maximum gusts: 90 km/h, except 110 along parts of the coast beginning Saturday until Sunday. Total snowfall: 15 to 30 cm continuing until Sunday morning. Locations: Hopedale and vicinity. Remarks: Snow will continue today through Saturday. Strong northerly winds will develop on Saturday. The combination of snowfall and strong winds will cause blowing snow, especially over exposed areas. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and strong winds today through Sunday. Total snowfall: 30 to 50 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 110 km/h. Locations: Postville and Makkovik. Time span: continuing until Sunday afternoon. Remarks: Snow at times heavy will ease tonight and become heavy at times again on Saturday. The snow is expected to persist into Sunday. Strong northerly winds will develop Saturday afternoon and ease Sunday afternoon. The combination of snowfall and strong winds will cause blowing snow, especially over exposed areas. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-30T07:06:06-00:00

Area: Postville - Makkovik
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm is expected. Heavy snow Friday and Saturday in Pangnirtung. A low pressure system developing in the western Arctic will move into Foxe Basin today. At Pangnirtung, snow will begin Friday morning and gradually intensify through the day. Most of the accumulating snow is expected Friday night and Saturday. The snow will ease on Saturday night with periods of light snow expected on Sunday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-30T01:25:56-00:00

Area: Pangnirtung
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Flurries at times heavy are expected. Snow squalls are likely as a cold northerly flow develops over the Gulf of St. Lawrence. Total snowfall: locally up to 20 cm by Saturday afternoon. Locations: Northern mainland Nova Scotia and western Prince Edward Island. Time span: This afternoon until Saturday evening. Remarks: Flurries at times heavy will develop this afternoon and will persist tonight and Saturday. Snow squalls with locally poor visibility are likely as well. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-30T06:35:48-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Persistent snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Snow squalls with total amounts of 20 to 40 cm is expected. Locations: Northern mainland Nova Scotia, Cape Breton Highlands and eastern Prince Edward Island. Time span: This afternoon to Saturday evening. Remarks: A cold northerly flow and strong winds will lead to the development of snow squalls starting this afternoon. Accumulations will vary with the intensity of the snow squalls with the highest amounts expected over the Cape Breton Highlands. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snow squall warnings are issued when bands of snow form that produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-30T06:36:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-29T14:37:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0973988727.2019
Area: Kings County P.E.I., Queens County P.E.I.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A mixture of significant wintry precipitation will continue. Total snowfall: 5 to 10 cm, except 20 to 30 cm inland and over higher terrain. Total rainfall: 20 to 30 mm along the coast. Locations: Baie Verte Peninsula. Time span: this afternoon until Saturday evening. Remarks: Snow and rain will continue this afternoon, before turning to mainly rain overnight. Snow will begin to redevelop on Saturday however, and become heavy, at times in the afternoon. Snowfall accumulations will be highly variable, with the highest totals occurring inland and over higher elevations. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-30T06:33:35-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant amounts of precipitation are expected. Total snowfall: near 10 cm inland and over higher terrain. Total rainfall: 20 to 40 mm along the coast. Locations: Burgeo area to the Connaigre Peninsula. Time span: continuing until this afternoon for the Connaigre Peninsula and until Saturday evening over the Burgeo highway. Remarks: Precipitation will gradually taper off on Saturday. Motorists are advised to be prepared for winter driving conditions over inland areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A wintry mix of significant high-elevation snowfall and coastal rainfall is expected. Total snowfall: 30 to 50 cm over the Long Range Mountains. Much less along the coast. Total rainfall: 20 to 30 mm along the coast. Locations: western and northern Newfoundland. Time span: this afternoon until Sunday morning. Remarks: A prolonged wintry mix of precipitation is expected. While coastal areas will receive mainly rain, snow will be dominant across the high country. Accumulations will vary considerably, with the largest totals occurring over the highest elevations of the Long Range Mountains. Anyone planning travel across higher parts of the Trans Canada Highway, Viking Trail or Roddickton Highway should expect winter driving conditions. Users of backcountry trails should be prepared for large amounts of snowfall. Conditions may deteriorate suddenly over short distances. ### Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-30T06:34:54-00:00

Remarks: A mixture of rain and snow will transition to snow at times heavy tonight and persist into Sunday. Strong northerly winds will develop Saturday afternoon and ease Sunday afternoon. properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Strong winds on Friday in Cape Dorset. Strong west to southwest winds will occur in Cape Dorset. Sustained winds of 60 to 70 km/h with gusts of 80 to 90 km/h will be in place for much of Friday. The wind is expected to strengthen as it shifts to the southwest later this afternoon, resulting in sustained winds near 70 km/h with gusts of 90 to 100 km/h through the evening hours. The wind will diminish overnight into Saturday morning. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

Area: Cape Dorset
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A Pacific warm front crossing northern Yukon today will bring snow to the Dempster and strong winds near the Richardson Mountains. East winds of 70 km/h gusting to 90 will develop late this morning giving poor visibility in blowing snow. Winds are forecast to diminish tonight as the front moves out of the region. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-30T04:46:54-00:00

Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Accumulating snow inland today. Significant rainfall along the coast today, tonight and Saturday. Total snowfall: 5 to 10 cm inland. Total rainfall: 25 to 40 mm. Locations: northeast coast of Newfoundland. Time span: this morning until Saturday afternoon. Remarks: Snow inland and rain along the coast will continue today before changing to showers or drizzle later today or early tonight. Rain will then continue into Saturday. Snowfall accumulations will be variable, with the highest accumulations likely occurring inland and over elevated terrain. Motorists are advised to be prepared for winter driving conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
